case_name: Palai Central Bank, Ltd. v. Reserve Bank of India

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 487 of 1961 filed by special leave from Kerala High Court judgment dated December 5, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 487 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 5, 1960. of the Kerala High Court in Baking Companies Petition No. 11 of 1960.

facts.text: Reserve Bank of India made application on August 8, 1960 in Kerala High Court under s.38 Banking Companies Act for winding up of Palai Central Bank Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: HIDAYATULLAH, J.-On August 8, 1960, the Reserve Bank of India made an application in the High Court of Kerala under s. 38 of the Banking Companies Act, 1949  10 of 1949  read with the Companies Act, 1956  1 of 1956 , for the winding up of the Palai Central Bank, Ltd.

facts.text: Palai Central Bank Ltd incorporated in January 1927 under Travancore Companies Regulations.

anchor.surface_text: The Palai Central Bank, Ltd.  herein referred as the Palai Bank or the Bank  was incorporated in January, 1927 under the Travancore Companies Regulations.

facts.text: Name changed from The Central Bank Ltd to Palai Central Bank in 1936.

anchor.surface_text: Till 1936, it was known as ,The Central Bank, Ltd when the name was changed.

facts.text: Palai Bank included in Second Schedule to Reserve Bank of India Act in March 1937.

anchor.surface_text: In March 1937, the Palai Bank was included in the Second Schedule to the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934  2 of 1934 .

facts.text: Paid-up capital of Palai Bank as per balance sheet year ending December 31, 1959 was Rs. 24,89,639.53.

anchor.surface_text: According to the balance sheet of the Palai Bank for the year ending December 31, 1959, the paid-up capital was Rs. 24,89,639.53.

facts.text: Nominal capital Rs. 40 lakhs divided into 1,60,000 equity shares of Rs.25 each.

anchor.surface_text: The numberinal capital of the Palai Bank was Rs. 40 lakhs divided into 1,60,000 equity shares of Rs.25/-

facts.text: Deposits grew from Rs. 77,000 in 1928 to almost Rs. 10 crores by 1960.

anchor.surface_text: In 1928, the deposits were a mere Rs. 77,000/-, but by 1960, they had become almost Rs. 10 crores.

facts.text: Palai Bank had 25 branches in and outside Kerala.

anchor.surface_text: It had 25 branches in and outside the State of Kerala.

facts.text: RBI inspections of Palai Bank in 1951, July 1953, Feb-Mar 1956, Mar 1958, Jan-Feb 1960.

anchor.surface_text: These inspections were made in 1951, July 1953, FebruaryMarch 1956, March 1958 and January- February, 1960.

facts.text: RBI found irregularities in advances: unsound, irrecoverable/sticky, unrealised interest, large advances to directors on inadequate security.

anchor.surface_text: Every time the Reserve Bank found irre- gularities which were pointed out to the Bank, and special directions were issued. The main defects were that the advances made by the Palai Bank were number sound that the bulk of the advances were either irrecoverable or sticky

facts.text: Bank declaring dividends without provision for bad debts, depleting reserves while deposits declined.

anchor.surface_text: and that the Bank was declaring dividends on the basis of profits which were companyputed without making provision for bad and doubtful debt and by issuing up the reserves at an alarming rate, while the deposits were going down.

facts.text: As of Dec 31, 1955, advances Rs. 355.02 lakhs, irrecoverable Rs. 171.27 lakhs, deposits impaired by Rs. 139.13 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the inspection in FebruaryMarch, 1956, the Reserve Bank avers, it was found that on December 31, 1955, the advances stood at Rs. 355.02 lakhs, of which Rs. 171-27 lakhs were irrecoverable, and that the deposits of the Bank had been impaired by Rs. 139- 13 lakhs.

facts.text: As of Feb 28, 1958, advances Rs. 421.56 lakhs, irrecoverable Rs. 208.05 lakhs, deposits impaired Rs. 177.24 lakhs after write-offs.

anchor.surface_text: in the inspection which was made in March-May, 1958, the position as on February 28, 1958, was found to be even worse. Though the deposits had gone up, the advances had raisen to Rs. 421.56 lakhs, of which Rs. 208.05 lakhs were said to be irrecoverable

facts.text: As of Dec 31, 1959, advances Rs. 529 lakhs, irrecoverable Rs. 218.51 lakhs, doubtful Rs. 17.71 lakhs, sticky Rs. 111.57 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: in the scrutiny in January-February, 1960, the position as on December 31, 1959, was said to be that out of the advances of Rs. 529 lakhs, Rs. 218.51 lakhs were irrecoverable, Rs. 17.71 lakhs were doubtful, and Rs. 111.57 lakbs were frozen or sticky.

facts.text: RBI letter on July 21, 1960 warning bank and giving 12 months to improve, 30 days to reply.

anchor.surface_text: On July 21, 1960, the Reserve Bank issued a letter companytaining the warnings to which the Palai Bank appeared to have become indurated, and further gave the Bank 12 months time to improve matters and 30 days to reply to the inspection report.

facts.text: Mr. Sivaraman (State Bank of India) appointed General Manager of Palai Bank on July 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: An Officer of the State Bank of India  Mr. Sivaraman  had already been deputed as the General Manager of the Palai Bank, and had taken charge on July 1, 1960.

facts.text: Balance sheet published June 23, 1960 showing loss of Rs. 14.5 lakhs for year ending Dec 31, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On June 23, 1960,the balance sheet of the Bank was published showing the position as on December 31, 1959. The balance sheet showed a loss of Rs. 14-1/2 lakhs.

facts.text: Run on bank in June 1960; deposits fell from Rs. 9.82 crores (June 24) to Rs. 9.32 crores (July 22), Rs. 8.50 crores (Aug 3).

anchor.surface_text: In June 1960, there was a run on several branches of the Palai Bank. ... Between June 24, 1960  deposits, Rs. 9.82 crores  and July 22, 1960  deposits, Rs. 9.32 crores  there was a withdrawal of Rs. 50 lakhs. By August 3, 1960  deposits, 8.50 crores

facts.text: Kerala High Court allowed RBI application on December 5, 1960, ordered winding up of Palai Bank.

anchor.surface_text: This application was allowed on December 5, 1960, and the present appeal with special leave, has been filed against the order. ... On December 5,1960, he acceptedthe application of the Reserve Bank, and ordered that thePalai Bank be wound up.

facts.text: Appellant Mr. Joseph Kuruvilla Velluvunnel, former director and contributory, obtained special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Company Judge, in his judgment under appeal, estimated that Rs. 158 lakhs  about one-sixth of the deposits  represented the sudden withdrawals. ... He was moved for a certificate under Art. 13 1  of the Constitution by the present appellant  Mr. Joseph Kuruvilla Vellukunnel , a former Director of the Palai Bank

facts.text: Run subsiding per bank affidavits, continuing per RBI.

anchor.surface_text: The Bank alleges in its affidavits in reply that the run was subsiding, while the Reserve Bank maintains that it was going on unabated.

facts.text: Company Judge estimated Rs. 158 lakhs (one-sixth deposits) sudden withdrawals.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Company Judge, in his judgment under appeal, estimated that Rs. 158 lakhs  about one-sixth of the deposits  represented the sudden withdrawals.

facts.text: Directors sent Mr. Sivaraman to Bombay mid-Aug 1960; he announced winding up application on Aug 8.

anchor.surface_text: The Directors of the Palai Bank sent Mr. Sivaraman on August 960, to Bombay for urgent companysultations, and Mr. Sivaraman on his return, announced on the 8th that in application for the winding up of the Bank had been made that day

facts.text: RBI dispensed notice under s.450(2) Companies Act, appointed provisional liquidator.

anchor.surface_text: He dispensed with numberice under s. 450 2  of the Companies Act before passing the order appointing the provisional Liquidator.

holdings.text: The provisions of ss. 38(1) and 38(3)(b)(iii) of the Banking Companies Act cannot be said to be a breach of Art. 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, the provisions of ss. 38(1) and 38(3)(b)(iii) cannot be said to be a breach of Art. 14 of the Constitution. That leaves over the second and third arguments,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Banking companies form a distinct class from non-banking companies due to paramount depositor interests justifying special winding-up procedure; differences related to legislative end of protection.

holdings.text: ss. 38(1) and (3)(b)(iii) of the Banking Companies Act do not impose unreasonable restrictions under Articles 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: the narrow question is whether in leaving this decision to the Reserve Bank the law offends the principles of natural justice, and becomes so unreasonable, viewed in the light

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delegation to RBI reasonable given its expertise, prior opportunities via inspections, and urgency in banking crises; protects depositors without violating rights.

holdings.text: Principles of natural justice are satisfied under s.38; prior inspections and communications constitute sufficient hearing.

anchor.surface_text: The objection that the Reserve Bank gives no hearing, records no reasons in writing and does not communicate them is met at least in this case by the admitted facts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nine years of inspections, directions, and warnings provided ample prior hearing; emergency from bank run justifies no further pre-application hearing.

holdings.text: s.38(1) mandates High Court to order winding up of banking company on RBI application if continuance prejudicial to depositors; excludes s.433 Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: section 433 and section 583 of the Companies Act., 1956, but without prejudice to its powers

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special procedure for banking companies valid due to distinct nature and depositor protection need; 'shall' is mandatory notwithstanding Companies Act provisions.

holdings.text: RBI's opinion under s.38(3)(b)(iii) that continuance prejudicial is binding on court and reasonable.

anchor.surface_text: between the Court and the Reserve Bank, the momentous decision to wind up a tottering or unsafe banking company in the interests of the depositors, may reasonably be left

holdings.reasoning_summary: RBI as expert central bank with intimate knowledge suited for swift decisions in crises; court would rely on RBI anyway; no need for prior judicial determination.

holdings.text: s.38 BCA upheld against Arts.14,19,301; no discrimination or unreasonable restriction.

anchor.surface_text: We are thus concerned with the contention that ss. 38(1) and (3)(b)(iii) are void, being a breach of Arts. 14 and 19 of the Constitution, and ultra vires being in conflict with Art. 301.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid classification, prior hearings, expediency in banking regulation; distinguishes detention/association cases as based on concrete facts not suspicion.

holdings.text: Dispensing with notice under s.450(2) Companies Act before provisional liquidator appointment proper.

anchor.surface_text: He dispensed with notice under s. 450 2  of the Companies Act before passing the order appointing the provisional Liquidator.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Emergency situation from bank run justified; affirmed lower court order.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General, on the other side, drew our attention to Virendra v. The State of Punjab  1 , where it has been pointed out that in judging the reasonableness of any particular law the surrounding circumstances in which the impugned law came to be enacted, the underlying purpose of the enactment and the extent and urgency of the evil sought to be remedied must also be companysidered.

IX, XIII and XVIA of Corpus Juris Secundum and from the Law Reports, particularly Title Guaranty and Surety Co. v. Idaho Ex Rd. Allen 1 , Bushnell v. Leland  2 , Ex parte Chetwood  3  and some others.

precedents.case_name: Title Guaranty and Surety Co. v. Idaho ex rel. Allen
precedents.cited_proposition: validity of statutes for liquidation of banks by executive officials

anchor.surface_text: Title Guaranty and Surety Co. v. Idaho Ex Rd. Allen 1 , Bushnell v. Leland  2 , Ex parte Chetwood  3  and some others. Mr. Nambiar, however, joined issue on the use of the American precedents on the grounds that banking in America is by grace of legislature,

Bushnell v. Leland  2 , Ex parte Chetwood  3  and some others. Mr. Nambiar, however, joined issue on the use of the American precedents on the grounds that banking in America is by grace of legislature, and is either a franchise or a privilege, which has numberplace in our Constitution.

precedents.cited_proposition: executive closure of national banks does not violate due process
